events.id: PADI Advanced Open Water Course-New Zealand Sea Adventures,9 Marina View, Mana, Wellington 5026, New Zealand, Wellington-All Events In
events.name: PADI Advanced Open Water Course
events.venue: New Zealand Sea Adventures,9 Marina View, Mana, Wellington 5026, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
PADI Advanced Open Water Course
“Your Next Step in Underwater Adventure”
Exploration excitement and experiences are what the PADI Advanced Open Water
course is all about. And no you don't have to be "advanced" to take it - it's designed
so both new and experienced Open Water Divers can sign up and develop better
diving skills and techniques straight away!

The Advanced Open Water Diver course helps you increase your confidence and
build scuba skills to become safer and more comfortable in the water. It’s also a great
way to get more diving experience under the supervision of a PADI Instructor.
This course builds on what you've learnt and develops new capabilities by
introducing new dive activities and ways to have fun scuba diving. You will complete
5 different types of dives to build your confidence and develop your dive skills. The
dives include the basics of Deep Diving Underwater Navigation - and your choice of
Peak Performance Buoyancy Naturalist Fish Identification Wreck (weather dependant)
Enriched Air * Photography or Night during winter.

Complete the theory online then join us for a weekends diving. After the 5 dives
over the weekend you will qualify as a PADI Advanced Open Water Diver. This is the
minimum requirement for many of our dive adventures and a prerequisite for the
PADI Rescue Diver course.

If you have any questions please call so we can help you.

events.id: Anna Fält and Ira Hadžić - Night 2-Pyramid Club,272 Taranaki Street, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: Anna Fält and Ira Hadžić - Night 2
events.venue: Pyramid Club,272 Taranaki Street, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Anna Fält and Ira Hadžić - Night 2
Our guest artists Anna Fält (Finland/Sweden) and Ira Hadžić (Germany) in improvised collaborations with local musicians Ritual Heaps, DSLB and Erika Grant.

Ira Hadžić is a Berlin-based sound artist whose musical practice moves at the intersections of improvisation, composition, and introspection. She works with gongs, radiophonic pieces, field recordings, resonances, simple sonic gestures – as well as silence as an expressive form in its own right. Trained as a Deep Listening facilitator at the Center for Deep Listening (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute), she incorporates these practices into her compositions and sound installations.

https://www.irahadzic.com/
https://ir-a.bandcamp.com/
https://www.instagram.com/irahadzic/

Anna Fält is a versatile voice artist, composer and singing teacher who is passionate about Nordic folk singing. She´s been touring Nordic countries and outside Europe for years with her unique concept of solo vocal concerts. Specialising in singing traditions from her two home countries Finland and Sweden, she combines the bright Scandinavian and dark East-European tones, performing in churches, museums, festivals, clubs and concert halls.

https://annafaltenglish.wordpress.com/

Presale tickets available via UTR

Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme
events.description:
Ira Hadžić is a Berlin-based sound artist whose musical practice moves at the intersections of improvisation, composition, and introspection.
She works with gongs, radiophonic pieces, field recordings, resonances, simple sonic gestures – as well as silence as an expressive form in its own right.
Trained as a Deep Listening facilitator at the Center for Deep Listening (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute), she incorporates these practices into her compositions and sound installations.
She´s been touring Nordic countries and outside Europe for years with her unique concept of solo vocal concerts.
Specialising in singing traditions from her two home countries Finland and Sweden, she combines the bright Scandinavian and dark East-European tones, performing in churches, museums, festivals, clubs and concert halls.

events.id: SUMAC - WELLINGTON - VALHALLAH-Valhalla,154 Vivian Street, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: SUMAC - WELLINGTON - VALHALLAH
events.venue: Valhalla,154 Vivian Street, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
SUMAC - WELLINGTON - VALHALLAH
Banished Music, Whammy Bar, and Valhalla are proud to present the long-awaited New Zealand debut of experimental post-metal trio SUMAC.
Formed in 2014, the powerhouse trio comprised of Aaron Turner (guitar, vocals; Isis, Old Man Gloom), Brian Cook (bass; Russian Circles, Botch), and Nick Yacyshyn (drums; Baptists) are renowned for merging crushing heaviness with improvisational freedom, exploring the boundaries between structure and chaos.

SUMAC have built a reputation as a fearsome live band. Visceral and cathartic shows where crushing riffs & sprawling drones collide with extended bursts of wild improvisation. In 2024, the band released their critically acclaimed album The Healer, a sweeping, transformative work spanning four monumental tracks. The record dives deep into themes of regeneration, suffering, and spiritual reconstruction — a testament to the band’s ability to meld raw power with emotional depth.

The experimental metal trio’s four-song, 76-minute album is the peak of their career. It’s dense and invigorating, highlighting the band’s dexterity, creativity, and clarity of purpose. - Pitchfork

Soon after the release SUMAC teamed up with poet and sound artist Moor Mother to release The Film, a boundary-pushing collaborative album. Released via Thrill Jockey in April 2025, the record unfolds as a cinematic journey across eight “scenes,” merging SUMAC’s heavy, jazz-inflected textures with Moor Mother’s incisive spoken-word commentary.

SUMAC’s work has always been about transition between different states of being. Our sense of normal, and indeed our sense of life, is now being shaken. We don’t know what is coming next. We are looking for pointers towards the future, as well as things to hold onto in the moment.
New Zealanders, don’t miss this rare and powerful journey into uncharted sonic terrain.

SUMAC have built a reputation as a fearsome live band.

events.id: Tết Cooking Workshop - Celebrate Lunar New Year Through Food-27 Hillary Court, Naenae, Lower Hutt 5011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Tết Cooking Workshop - Celebrate Lunar New Year Through Food
events.venue: 27 Hillary Court, Naenae, Lower Hutt 5011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Step into the flavours of Vietnamese Lunar New Year with a special hands-on workshop that brings tradition, community, and storytelling together.
Join us as part of the Lunar New Year Festival 2026 for a delicious cultural experience!
✨ What We’ll Make Together:
🍃 Bánh Tét / Bánh Chưng – iconic sticky rice cakes wrapped in banana leaves, symbolising family reunion and prosperity
🥒 Dưa Món (Pickled Vegetables) – crunchy, colourful pickles that balance the richness of New Year dishes
🍖 Thịt Kho (Caramelized Braised Pork) – tender pork simmered in coconut water, a dish that brings comfort, warmth and the taste of Tết
This workshop is designed for all ages — beginners, families, food lovers, and anyone curious about Vietnamese culture. Learn the meaning behind each dish and how they come together on every Vietnamese New Year table.
💛 Why Join?
• Experience authentic Vietnamese Tết traditions
• Learn recipes passed down through generations
• Connect with community through shared stories and food
• Take home what you cook
• Celebrate culture in a warm, hands-on environment
Sponsored & partnered with Pomare Taita Community Trust, E Tū Whānau & Hutt City Council.

events.name: Gallop Into the New Year: Lunar Celebrations in the Hutt
events.venue: 45 Laings Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Gallop Into the New Year: Lunar Celebrations in the Hutt 🐎
Proudly sponsored by Hutt City Council
📍 Dowse Square & Lower Hutt Town Hall
📅 Saturday, 31 January 2026
🕚 11:00 AM – 4:00 PM
Join us for a colourful, family-friendly Lunar New Year Festival in the heart of Lower Hutt!
Organised by Viet Hub NZ and proudly sponsored by Hutt City Council, this outdoor cultural festival celebrates not only Vietnamese Tết but also embraces wider Lunar New Year traditions from diverse communities across Aotearoa.
Let’s gallop into the Year of the Horse together through music, food, stories, and joyful celebration!
🎭 What to Expect:
Outdoor Cultural Market: Featuring authentic street food, handmade crafts, and local community stalls
Live Stage Performances: Lion dance, drumming, cultural dances, and musical acts throughout the day
Cultural Games & Crafts: Hands-on activities like calligraphy, lantern making, and Vietnamese folk games
Storytelling Exhibition: An indoor showcase of migration stories, heritage, and identity from local residents
Traditional Costume Photo Corner: Indoor area to take photos in Vietnamese and cultural New Year outfits
Family Fun: Face painting, interactive workshops, lucky draws, and more.
🎟️ Tickets:
Free General Admission – Register to stay updated and be entered in giveaways
Optional Donation – Help us grow this community-led festival and support ongoing Viet Hub NZ programme
💛 Why You Should Come:
This is Lower Hutt’s largest, most inclusive Lunar New Year celebration, designed for all ages and backgrounds. Whether you’re reconnecting with your heritage or discovering new traditions — everyone is welcome.
📢 Stay Connected:
Follow us on Facebook or visit www.viethubnz.org
📧 Contact us: hello@viethubnz.org
🫶 This event is made possible thanks to the generous support of Hutt City Council and our amazing volunteers, artists, and community partners.

Formed in 2014, the powerhouse trio comprised of Aaron Turner (guitar, vocals; Isis, Old Man Gloom), Brian Cook (bass; Russian Circles, Botch), and Nick Yacyshyn (drums; Baptists) are renowned for merging crushing heaviness with improvisational freedom, exploring the boundaries between structure and chaos.

In 2024, the band released their critically acclaimed album The Healer, a sweeping, transformative work spanning four monumental tracks. The record dives deep into themes of regeneration, suffering, and spiritual reconstruction — a testament to the band’s ability to meld raw power with emotional depth.
The experimental metal trio’s four-song, 76-minute album is the peak of their career. It’s dense and invigorating, highlighting the band’s dexterity, creativity, and clarity of purpose. - Pitchfork
Soon after the release SUMAC teamed up with poet and sound artist Moor Mother to release The Film, a boundary-pushing collaborative album. Released via Thrill Jockey in April 2025, the record unfolds as a cinematic journey across eight “scenes,” merging SUMAC’s heavy, jazz-inflected textures with Moor Mother’s incisive spoken-word commentary.
SUMAC’s work has always been about transition between different states of being. Our sense of normal, and indeed our sense of life, is now being shaken. We don’t know what is coming next. We are looking for pointers towards the future, as well as things to hold onto in the moment.
New Zealanders, don’t miss this rare and powerful journey into uncharted sonic terrain.

The experimental metal trio’s four-song, 76-minute album is the peak of their career. It’s dense and invigorating, highlighting the band’s dexterity, creativity, and clarity of purpose. - Pitchfork

Soon after the release SUMAC teamed up with poet and sound artist Moor Mother to release The Film, a boundary-pushing collaborative album. Released via Thrill Jockey in April 2025, the record unfolds as a cinematic journey across eight “scenes,” merging SUMAC’s heavy, jazz-inflected textures with Moor Mother’s incisive spoken-word commentary. 

SUMAC’s work has always been about transition between different states of being. Our sense of normal, and indeed our sense of life, is now being shaken. We don’t know what is coming next. We are looking for pointers towards the future, as well as things to hold onto in the moment. 
New Zealanders, don’t miss this rare and powerful journey into uncharted sonic terrain.
events.description:
Formed in 2014, the powerhouse trio comprised of Aaron Turner (guitar, vocals; Isis, Old Man Gloom), Brian Cook (bass; Russian Circles, Botch), and Nick Yacyshyn (drums; Baptists) are renowned for merging crushing heaviness with improvisational freedom, exploring the boundaries between structure and chaos.
SUMAC have built a reputation as a fearsome live band.
Visceral and cathartic shows where crushing riffs & sprawling drones collide with extended bursts of wild improvisation.
The record dives deep into themes of regeneration, suffering, and spiritual reconstruction — a testament to the band’s ability to meld raw power with emotional depth.
The experimental metal trio’s four-song, 76-minute album is the peak of their career.

events.id: River City Express-Paekakariki Railway Station,Paekakariki, Paekakariki , New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: River City Express
events.venue: Paekakariki Railway Station,Paekakariki, Paekakariki , New Zealand
events.long_description:
River City Express
Travel to the beautiful river side town of Whanganui, hauled by both steam locomotive Ab 608 and diesel locomotive Da 1410. Choose between doing your own thing, or jumping on a serene cruise of the Whanganui River onboard the coal fired paddle steamer "PS Waimarie".

Leaving Kapiti as most others are still sound asleep, we quickly escape the coast and delve into the rurality of the Horowhenua. After a stop in Palmerston North we head up the trunk through the townships of Feilding and Marton before turning onto the Marton - New Plymouth railway line for the last stretch into Whanganui. After crossing the 290km long Whanganui River, we proceed slowly down the short 5km branch line taking us to Taupo Quay.

TRAVEL ON THE PADDLE STEAMER WAIMARIE!
Salvaged from the bottom of the Whanganui River where she sat for around 50 years, the Paddle Steamer Waimarie was restored to her former glory and re-launched in 2000. She is now the only one of her kind in operation in New Zealand. Your cruise leaves the Riverboat Centre Wharf and heads upriver taking in the scenery and views of Whanganui which can only be experienced from Te Awa Tupua, the Whanganui River. The commentary shares riverboat history and points of interest along the way. Check out the boiler that powers our paddle steamer, and maybe meet the homing pigeons and send a message with them on their flight back to the Riverboat Centre.

Departing Paekakariki/Paraparaumu/Waikanae/Otaki/Levin
Adult 13+ yrs - $209
Child 2-12yrs - $179

Departing Palmerston North/Feilding
Adult 13+ yrs - $189
Child 2-12yrs - $169

Buses will transport you from your arrival at the station to the Waimarie River Boat Centre.

DO YOUR OWN THING!
There will be a collection of vintage cruiser bikes for hire for a small fee to those keen to take exploring to the next level.

There will be short tours available at the Durie Hill Elevator. It is New Zealand’s only public transport elevator and is still used on a daily basis by locals and visitors.

There are multiple places to go, and things to see on a cruiser bike or on foot. Take a tram ride for a small fee and arrive at the Riverboat museum, be blown away by NZ Glassworks, admire the sculptures and views from the Motua gardens along the river, indulge in local cuisine, or simply shop local.

Departing Paekakariki/Paraparaumu/Waikanae/Otaki/Levin
Adult 13+ yrs - $159
Child 2-12yrs - $139

Departing Palmerston North/Feilding
Adult 13+ yrs - $139
Child 2-12yrs - $119

Book at https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/river-city-express/

events.id: Ludovico Einaudi-Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Ludovico Einaudi
events.venue: Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
His music has been performed live on an Arctic ice-floe and as soundtracks for Oscar and Golden Globe-winning films. Italian pianist and composer Ludovico Einaudi is returning to Wellington with a new album to explore with audiences. The Michael Fowler Centre will be filled with Ludovico’s special mix of neo-classical, pop, ambient, rock, and experimental styles. His modern soundscapes are renowned for being able to cross artistic and generational boundaries. Because of this, he has become one of the world’s most-streamed classical music artists. 
Ludovico began composing in the 1980s for theatre and ballet. He has since gone on to write for film and television and produce multi-million-selling albums. His most recent is ‘The Summer Portraits’. Written in 2025, it is the result of a cascade of personal memories triggered by sun, summer, and family holidays. Here, he returns to the lush full-band textures of earlier works. You’ll get to hear this first-hand, so don’t miss your chance.

events.long_description:
LAMMAS FULL MOON SONG AND SOUND CEREMONY
Come and Sing, Sound and Meditate!

Want to mark the important time of the JANUARY/ fEBRUARY LAMMAS full moon? Lammas is the Celtic festival of the first Harvest.

Come and join with us on Sunday the 1st February for a group ceremonial gathering in Paraparaumu.

We will explore sacred conscious sounding practices to balance and align the energy system, sing healing chants and songs from different traditions, and explore guided vocal improvisation for freedom, upliftment and joy!

Ceremonial cacao will be served with focus and healing intention.

There will be guided journal prompts around the energy of the Solstice and the whole session will finish with a full sound healing.

Everyone is welcome and there is no need for any particular preparation or pre existing skill.

Please get in touch with any questions or to book. Come and enjoy Song, Chant, Sound and Healing!!

So looking forward to gathering for the Lammas Full Moon. Come and join with us to invoke and celebrate the energies of balance, creation, abundance and celebration at this profound time of year.

This session will explore singing, chanting, sounding and conscious voice empowerment practices. We will also explore energy practices like Qigong and meditation. All within a ceremonial framework.

Everyone is welcome. Limited spaces. Get in touch soon

You are warmly invited to book to join this powerful sound and voice ceremony which will work with Spirit, the forces of Nature and Bryony's skill and expertise in creating sound for growth and transformation.

This is a special opportunity to tune into the sacred energies and potentialities of this time: opening us up to balance, healing, nourishment, new growth and positive change.

Bryony will invoke and work with the healing power of the supportive energies of Spirit, ancestors and our highest Selves. Bryony's has an extensive background experience with Spirit, the Earth forces and sacred lands; these forces are central to her practice and Self.

She will lead you firstly in a process of meditation, conscious sounding, toning and singing healing chants.

This use of our voices to co-create a sacred group sound is uplifting and transformative and will support you in your process of healing, releasing and visioning.

There will be time for guided journaling and intention setting.

The second section of the workshop will be a focused and dedicated sound bath which will bring balance and deep relaxation, into a sense of stillness and peace. There can be a sense of gratitude and appreciation.

Both the conscious use of the voice and the sound healing have many benefits, which are verified by science and which can effect us positively on the physical, mental, emotional, energetic and spiritual levels. A document which has more information about these benefits can be provided on request.

All are welcome:
I look forward to sharing with you and supporting you in this ceremony.

Investment for full 2.5 hours

$59 - concession - https://buy.stripe.com/8wMaItcvY6oV0Kc7ti

events.id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Introductory Tour (Feb 2026)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Introductory Tour (Feb 2026)
events.venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Introductory Tour. 
This tour outlines the development of Karori Cemetery since the first burial in August 1891, traversing the earliest burial areas which contain many interesting memorials and monuments. 
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 45 minutes to one hour long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

events.id: Ludovico Einaudi | Wellington - Michael Fowler Centre-Michael Fowler Centre-All Events In
events.name: Ludovico Einaudi | Wellington - Michael Fowler Centre
events.venue: Michael Fowler Centre
events.long_description:
Ludovico Einaudi | Wellington - Michael Fowler Centre
Ludovico Einaudi
Sunday 1 February 2026
Michael Fowler Centre

The world’s most popular classical music composer, Italian pianist, Ludovico Einaudi, returns to Australia and New Zealand this January with his new album The Summer Portraits.

He has performed on an Arctic ice-floe for Greenpeace and has seen his music become the soundtrack for Oscar and Golden Globe winning films ('Les Intouchables', 'Nomadland', 'The Father') and TikTok phenomena (his 2012 track 'Experience' exploded on the app) alike. From his earliest work composing for theatre and ballet in the 1980s to his multi-million-selling albums like 'In a Time Lapse' and his popular soundtracks across film and television, Einaudi has drawn upon neo-classical, pop, ambient, rock and experimental styles to create a sound that crosses boundaries and generations, becoming the world’s best known – and most streamed – classical music artist in the process.

In January 2025, Einaudi released 'The Summer Portraits'. The record is a lush return to full-band textures and is the result of a cascade of personal memories triggered by sun, summer and family holidays. On his last Australian tour, before a gig at the Sydney Opera House, Einaudi sat down and started composing the single 'Rose Bay', based on his sense impressions of the bay his grandfather made home.

Don’t miss your chance to experience the world’s most popular contemporary classical artist.

He has performed on an Arctic ice-floe for Greenpeace and has seen his music become the soundtrack for Oscar and Golden Globe winning films ('Les Intouchables', 'Nomadland', 'The Father') and TikTok phenomena (his 2012 track 'Experience' exploded on the app) alike.
From his earliest work composing for theatre and ballet in the 1980s to his multi-million-selling albums like 'In a Time Lapse' and his popular soundtracks across film and television, Einaudi has drawn upon neo-classical, pop, ambient, rock and experimental styles to create a sound that crosses boundaries and generations, becoming the world’s best known – and most streamed – classical music artist in the process.
In January 2025, Einaudi released 'The Summer Portraits'.
The record is a lush return to full-band textures and is the result of a cascade of personal memories triggered by sun, summer and family holidays.

events.id: Saving the Hutt’s Public Art Heritage-The Dowse Art Museum,45 Laings Road, Lower Hutt, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: Saving the Hutt’s Public Art Heritage
events.venue: The Dowse Art Museum,45 Laings Road, Lower Hutt, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Saving the Hutt’s Public Art Heritage
Public artworks hold stories of place, identity and change. How do we protect and share our heritage?

About this Event

Public artworks are more than simple decoration. They hold stories of place, identity and change. When the spaces around them shift, those stories can be at risk. Who carries responsibility for protecting heritage works, and how do we ensure they remain part of our shared future?
The early spark for The Wheel of Avalon began when artist Bronwyn Holloway-Smith was invited to Avalon TV Studios in her role as Co-Director of Public Art Heritage Aotearoa New Zealand. There, viewing Bill McCardle’s mosaic mural, she reflected: “The story of the mural feels like a metaphor for the rise and fall of Avalon Studios.”
Join Holloway-Smith for an engaging and thought-provoking talk exploring this work alongside a Guy Ngan mural in Naenae and a piece by E. Mervyn Taylor in Taita. Together, these three recent projects reveal different approaches to safeguarding the Hutt’s public art heritage and open a conversation about what proactive, future-focused care and preservation of public art could look like in the years ahead.

Dr Bronwyn Holloway-Smith (Pākehā) is an award-winning conceptual artist, author, and researcher. Her interdisciplinary practice spans public art, digital media and deep-dive research, often focused on the tangled legacies of cultural memory, Pākehā identity, and the politics of preservation. She lives on Pōneke's rugged south coast with her partner and their three offspring.

events.id: Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026-Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026
events.venue: Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz

events.name: Malcolm Todd tickets
events.venue: Meow Nui, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Presented by: Handsome Tours & Laneway
Handsome Tours and Laneway Presents are proud to present Malcolm Todd!
Los Angeles-born songwriter Malcolm Todd has gone from scooping ice cream to racking up millions of streams in just a few years. After a viral breakthrough with ‘Roommates’ and his mixtape Sweet Boy (2024), Malcolm Todd doubled down with his 2025 self-titled debut album – a record that blends humour, honesty and restless ambition into a singular voice.
Featuring Omar Apollo on the standout single ‘Bleed’ the album captures Todd at his most fearless, pushing his pop instincts into bold new territory. With a devoted fanbase and a reputation for chaotic, heartfelt live shows, Malcolm Todd now makes his Australian and New Zealand debut with headline sideshows in Sydney, Melbourne and Wellington.

events.long_description:
Host Responsibility Training for all staff
Regular staff training is an important part of maintaining and renewing your premises' Alcohol Licence. We are bringing regular, in-person Host Responsibility training to you and your staff. We all know Hospitality venues can be fun and dynamic places to work, but serving alcohol carries a lot of responsibility.
Minimising harm and providing safer environments for the sale and supply of alcohol is a priority whether working in a restaurant, bar, hotel, club, or off-licence.
This Host Responsibility course is essential training that provides the following:
Knowledge of the law
The principles of responsible service
Practical tools for all staff working in licensed premises.
Book your team for this in-person training, which your regional manager will present.
If any of your team members can no longer attend after booking, please cancel the booking, as space is limited.

events.id: Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds — Wild God Tour-TSB Arena, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds — Wild God Tour
events.venue: TSB Arena, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Their music has long defied classification. For over 40 years, Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds have delivered a sophisticated mix of post-punk, experimental, gospel, and blues to adoring fans. Now, in a New Zealand exclusive, Wellington gets to hear them live at TSB Arena in February. Renowned for their exhilarating and unforgettable performances, the band is regarded as one of the most thrilling to watch on stage. 
In 2024, they released their eighteenth studio album, ‘Wild God’. Now, Nick and the band are circling the globe on the ‘Wild God Tour’. They have finished the North American and European legs, and TSB Arena on Wellington’s waterfront is the next stop off. The band will perform a setlist drawn from the latest album alongside songs spanning the four decades of a storied career.
Brought to you in association with Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. 
Tickets will go on sale to the public on Friday, 29 August at 10am.

events.id: Summer Camp | Sam Fowles and Elly Mae -San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Summer Camp | Sam Fowles and Elly Mae
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.long_description:
San Fran Summer Camp is back for 2026!

Join us and some of Te Whanganui-a-Tara’s finest artists over five nights across January and February with tickets from $10 or a season pass for $40, featuring drink specials and cocktails thanks to our sponsor Jameson.

Our penultimate night features two of Pōneke’s finest songwriters from two separate sonic worlds… their combination is sure to be a treat!

Sam Fowles makes music that moves the body, speaks to the heart, and touches the soul. Driven by groove and the desire to find meaning in the moments on this journey we call life, the musician, songwriter and producer has a signature sound that stands out and stuns. Fowles would describe his music as psychedelic soul laced with blues and funk. It resonates with deep grooves and driving rhythms created by vintage drum sounds, digital sonics, and electric guitars that build and blaze into billowing soundscapes. At its core is his unique, soulful voice and the punchy, heartfelt lyrics he wears on his sleeve.

Elly Mae crafts songs that encapsulate the bittersweet ache of growth, the quiet unraveling of time, and the soft glow of nostalgia embedded within. Her music is an amalgamation of folk, dreampop, indie, shoegaze, and anything in between. From lullabies that make you feel weightless to being wrapped in a blanket of sound, Elly Mae's folk/country melodic guitar style is accompanied by experimental, spatial bass from Arran Cargill-Brown and textured pocket drumming from Sasha Francis-Murray. 


San Fran holds a Supervised License, meaning minors are welcome to attend events at San Fran so long as they are accompanied by a legal guardian at all times whilst at the venue. Minors are of course not allowed to purchase alcohol under any circumstance.

events.id: Te Rā o Waitangi--Wellington NZ
events.name: Te Rā o Waitangi
events.long_description:
Te Rā o Waitangi is a free, whānau -friendly event to commemorate the signing of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and Aotearoa New Zealand’s national day. Kicking off at midday in Waitangi Park, you'll find the main stage programme packed with local talent. Enjoy live music, dance, and cultural performances. Dotted around Waitangi Park, you’ll also find a selection of delicious kai , stalls, a Kids’ Zone, a treaty education space, and much more. 
Te Rā o Waitangi 2026 acknowledges tūrangawaewae and whakapapa for all — where is the place you lay down your roots? Where is your family from? In 2026, Waitangi Day celebrates the things that we all share and the things that make us different.

events.name: FREE ENTRY: Waitangi Day in Porirua
events.venue: Te Rauparaha Park,Porirua, New Zealand
events.long_description:
FREE ENTRY: Waitangi Day in Porirua
FREE ENTRY:

We are glad to partner with mana whenua Ngāti Toa once again to deliver a fun-filled Waitangi Day event in Porirua, one of the largest Waitangi Day events to take place in New Zealand on our national day.

❤️ Waka tours are on once more!
🎤 Live music at Te Rauparaha Park
🥗 Food trucks will line Norrie Streets
😜 Fun for tamariki and rangatahi

Parking 🚙
Parking will be available on surrounding streets such as Wi Neera Drive or you can leave your car at the railway station and take the short walk to Te Rauparaha Park.

Cash 💳
It’s best to bring cash on the day as not all vendors will have eftpos available, although there are nearby ATMs on Lyttelton Avenue if you wish to top up.

The event will be alcohol-free, smoke/vape-free and there will be no dogs allowed.

events.id: Te Rā o Waitangi 2026-Waitangi Park,24A Herd St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington-All Events In
events.name: Te Rā o Waitangi 2026
events.venue: Waitangi Park,24A Herd St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
Te Rā o Waitangi 2026
Nau mai, haere mai! Join us to celebrate Te Rā o Waitangi 2026, Wellington City Council’s free annual Waitangi Day event ❤️🖤

Te Rā o Waitangi 2026 acknowledges tūrangawaewae and whakapapa for all!

Bring your friends and whānau to Waitangi Park from 12 noon to 6pm on Friday 6 February for live music, kai, activities celebrating Māori culture, and the spirit of Te Tiriti o Waitangi.

He aha kei te haere? What to expect:

✨ Live performances showcasing tangata whenua and tangata tiriti talent

✨ Multicultural food stalls and a fundraiser hāngi from midday (get in quick!)

✨ Arts, crafts, and family-friendly activities, including taonga tākaro Māori

✨Pacific Media Networks 531pi audience stage activations

✨ Stunning stage artwork created at the 2024 event by artists Keri-Mei Zagrobelna and Tina Rae Carter

✨ A Treaty Education Tent to learn, reflect, and connect

Gather your whānau and join us to honour our past, celebrate our present, and dream of our future together.

Alongside our Te Rā o Waitangi event, we’re excited to bring the free theatre roadshow ‘He Māori?’ by Īhaka Martyn and Taki Rua Productions, this Waitangi Day. Catch a performance at one of three locations:
🕙 10am–11.30am: Tawa Community Centre
🕜 1.30pm–3pm: Khandallah Community Centre
🕓 4pm–5.30pm: The Hannah Playhouse

All shows are free, but bookings are required.

For more information, the Te Rā o Waitangi Day programme and booking information: https://wellington.govt.nz/news-and-events/events-and-festivals/waitangi-day

Our Te Rā o Waitangi event is made possible by many, and we acknowledge our Tākai Here partners: Te Rūnanga O Toa Rangatira, Taranaki Whānui ki Te Upoko o te Ika and Te Rūnanganui o Te Āti Awa ki te Upoko o Te Ika a Māui.

He aha kei te haere?
Alongside our Te Rā o Waitangi event, we’re excited to bring the free theatre roadshow ‘He Māori?’ by Īhaka Martyn and Taki Rua Productions, this Waitangi Day.

events.id: Te Tiriti and Me – He Māori? by Īhaka Martyn at The Hannah-Hannah Playhouse,12 Cambridge Ter, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington-All Events In
events.name: Te Tiriti and Me – He Māori? by Īhaka Martyn at The Hannah
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse,12 Cambridge Ter, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
Te Tiriti and Me – He Māori? by Īhaka Martyn at The Hannah
Te Tiriti and Me – He Māori by Īhaka Martyn

Nau mai, haere mai! Join us to celebrate Te Rā o Waitangi 2026, with a free travelling Theatre Roadshow, He Māori? by Īhaka Martyn.

Alongside our Te Rā o Waitangi event, we are bringing Te Tiriti and Me back to Wellingtonians again. Last year saw a travelling forum series, and this year we welcome the free Theatre Roadshow 'He Māori?' by Īhaka Martyn, which is touring three locations on Waitangi Day:

📍Tawa Community Centre, 10am – 11.30am: https://events.humanitix.com/tawa-te-tiriti-and-me-2026-taki-rua-and-wcc-present-he-maori

📍Khandallah Community Centre, 1.30pm – 3pm: https://events.humanitix.com/khandallah-te-tiriti-and-me-2026-taki-rua-and-wcc-present-he-maori

📍The Hannah Playhouse, 4pm – 5.30pm: https://events.humanitix.com/the-hannah-te-tiriti-and-me-2026-taki-rua-and-wcc-present-he-maori

About He Māori:
Is 1/16th enough? Īhaka Martyn will have you laughing and crying as he weaves elements of stand-up comedy, waiata, and physical performance to explore the confusion, comedy and celebration of reclaiming his Māoritanga from a Pākehā upbringing. A 60 minute journey from total confusion to partial understanding. He aha? He Māori? Is he? Maybe - it depends.

He Māori? by Īhaka Martyn is presented in partnership with Taki Rua Productions and is suitable for all ages. There will be a Q&A session after each performance.

events.id: Paraparaumu, New Zealand-Raumati Social Club with Celia Farran and Melissa Cox-34 Poplar Ave, Raumati South, Paraparaumu 5032-All Events In
events.name: Paraparaumu, New Zealand-Raumati Social Club with Celia Farran and Melissa Cox
events.venue: 34 Poplar Ave, Raumati South, Paraparaumu 5032
events.long_description:
Paraparaumu, New Zealand-Raumati Social Club with Celia Farran and Melissa Cox
Join the Mystic Muses, award-winning singer/songwriters Melissa Cox (NZ/USA) and Celia Farran (USA) for an unforgettable show featuring Celtic music of the past, present, and future - Enya, Sinead O'Connor, The Cranberries, Loreena McKennitt, traditional tunes, lore & legends, sea shanties, and haunting original songs by Melissa and Celia.

-- Meet the Muses --

MELISSA COX: Multi-instrumentalist and award-winning songwriter Melissa Cox conjures a one-woman storm of Celtic tradition, tribal beats, and celestial synths to create an ethereal, danceable Elvish EDM dream. Using her looping pedal, she layers tin whistle, electric mandolin, piano, synths, drum beats, and her haunting voice to create performances reminiscent of Enigma, Enya, and Loreena McKennitt. A seasoned touring artist and classically trained vocalist, she pushes Celtic and World music into the 21st century with raw energy and fearless, honest lyrics. http://www.melcoxmusic.com

CELIA FARRAN: “A cross between an Earthy Enya, Joan Baez, and Tina Fey.” She dishes up the most delicious concoction of the silly and sacred, delighting audiences across the globe. With rusty red locks and twinkling eyes, she casts a spell of enchantment upon her listeners, bringing deep and resonating experiences to audiences across the globe. With powerful, heart-felt vocals and wacky comedic improvisations, the audience never knows what will happen with Celia on stage. http://www.celiafarran.com

events.id: TAWA Te Tiriti and Me 2026 - Taki Rua and WCC Present: He Māori?-5 Cambridge Street, Tawa, Wellington 5028, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: TAWA Te Tiriti and Me 2026 - Taki Rua and WCC Present: He Māori?
events.venue: 5 Cambridge Street, Tawa, Wellington 5028, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Te Tiriti and Me 
Wellingtonians talk about what Whakapapa and The Treaty of Waitangi means to them. 
What is it? 
After the successful delivery of Te Tiriti and Me on Waitangi Day this year, we are bringing the roadshow back! In 2026, we’re changing things up to a touring theatre show which has been designed to be presented in schools and community spaces: 
Taki Rua Productions and Īhaka Martyn present: He Māori? 
Īhaka Martyn will have you laughing and crying as he weaves elements of stand-up comedy, waiata and physical performance to explore the confusion, comedy and celebration of reclaiming his Māoritanga from a Pākehā upbringing. It is a journey from total confusion to partial understanding. 
He aha? He Māori? Is he? Maybe - it depends 
He Māori is a 60 minute performance with a short Q+A session afterwards. Suitable for all ages. 
All sessions are free, but require bookings due to venue capacities.
When is it? 
Thursday 6 February 2025 – Waitangi Day. You are warmly invited to join us for a free presentation of He Māori? Followed by a short Q+A. 
Te Tiriti and Me is part of WCC’s Te Rā o Waitangi celebrations.  Full community centre timetable below: 
10.00 - 11.30am  
SESSION #1 - Tawa Community Centre  
  1.30 - 3.00pm  
SESSION #2 - Khandallah Community Centre  
  4.00 - 5.30pm  
SESSION #3 – The Hannah Playhouse

🌿 ReConnected Foundations Workshop (10:00am - 2:00pm): Meditation, breathwork, and sound healing.
.
.
𝗛𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲'𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗼𝗳𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗱 𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗵?
𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗹𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘂𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘄𝗵𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽?

Life throws us surprises - big or small. You're not alone. We've been there too.
That's why we created this one-day experience - a chance for us all to reconnect with the paths that matter most to us!

Get ready for an inspiring experience with like-minded friends as we lead you toward discovering new clarity about yourself and your direction moving forward.

Don't wait any longer; start taking control now by saying yes to this extraordinary opportunity!

We’re bringing a one-day immersion of profound inner work to BULLS.

On Saturday, February 7th, at Te Matapihi Town Hall, 4 Criterion Street, Bulls 4818, New Zealand, we invite you to experience a powerful session designed to awaken, clear, and elevate your energy. Choose to embrace a deeper, more transformative journey. ❤️

This is a Foundations Workshop, a session designed to clear mental fog, restore balance, and ignite your inner spark through breathwork, meditation, and sound healing. 🧘‍♀️

All our previous events have sold out, so be sure to secure your spot early.

Love and gratitude,
Matt & Guy

events.long_description:
Hoe Down
Two massive days of historic cars at Harrisville!
While you are in town for the Teams Champs make sure you head out to NZ's best privately owned track!
Watch the historic cars and bikes hit the dirt and do some laps!
ALL Vintage open wheel - Saloon cars, sprint cars, Stock cars, TQs, Midgets, Modifieds, side cars and solo bikes.
Saturday and Sunday racing starts from 11:000am and finishes about 3:00pm. Prize giving to follow on Sunday.
Harrisville Speedway merchandise will be for sale, food trucks, coffee and cold drinks on site.
Spectators are welcome, entry is a gold coin per person.
To enter your car PM Harrisville Speedway with your name, class, car number and cell phone number.
$100 per car to enter for both days, extra drivers $30.00 per day.
Camping available $10 per person per night. You must register at the Saloon prior to setting up or you may be asked to move.
NO DOGS

Divine Connections is a holistic wellbeing and spiritualism event that offers psychic readings, spiritual + wellbeing supplies, handcrafted creations, giftware and various energetic and hands-on healing modalities.

Our events are about community, connection and wellness. They facilitate a space for like-minded lightworkers to connect with the public and offer their amazing gifts. Hauora is addressed on all four dimensions through our stallholders' many offerings; the physical, the mental, the spiritual and of course family. We are a family friendly event, so you can take this opportunity to connect with yourself or your loved ones on this plane as well as the next!

So come along, support a good cause and bask in the awesome atmosphere and aroha created by our collective of talented lightworkers!


Entry: Koha (digital donation available via Eventbrite)
Please bring cash, sorry No EFTPOS onsite.
Each stallholder has there own methods of payment and prices


We love welcoming new faces to our stallholder community, not only does it raise the vibration of the collective, it means that no two expos are ever the same. We also love to support our regular stallholders and their upcoming ventures. If anyone is interested in participating as a stallholder please message Divine Connections Expo on Facebook.

events.id: UNLEASH THE VOICES OF YOUR SUN AND MOON-Paraparaumu Memorial Hall-All Events In
events.name: UNLEASH THE VOICES OF YOUR SUN AND MOON
events.venue: Paraparaumu Memorial Hall
events.long_description:
UNLEASH THE VOICES OF YOUR SUN AND MOON
Book Soon for this special day workshop and explore and unleash the power of your Voice and Astrological Archetypes!!

We are blessed that Alignment Coach and Healer, Clare Babbage is visiting the Wellington Region from Napier, and collaborating with Voice Empowerment Coach and Healer, Bryony Rogers from Heartsong Healing, in this exciting, unique offering.

This workshop is a specially designed, transformative full day experience of Embodied Astrological Archetypes and Conscious Sound and Voice Practices.

BOOK HERE - https://buy.stripe.com/aEU3g1gMecNj2SkbJI

On the date of the full moon, the energies of the sun and the moon stand face to face — illuminating both our outer expression and our inner world.

In astrology, the sun represents our fullest expression, our vitality, and the way we are here to shine. The moon reveals our emotional landscape, our inner rhythms, and often the fears that arise when we dare to live that full expression. Together, they form a powerful dialogue between structure and flow, logic and emotion, masculine and feminine.

In this workshop, Clare will guide you into an embodied exploration of your own sun and moon, inviting you to feel these two archetypes within your body and notice where they support, resist, or balance each other.

Bryony will lead you into vocal practices that bring these energies into sound and voice — giving expression to what is often left unspoken. Through voice, you’ll release what holds you back and discover new harmony between your inner and outer selves.

This full moon is the perfect moment to unleash the voices of your sun and moon — and to step more fully into clarity, balance, and authentic expression.

The timing of this workshop gives you a unique opportunity to tune into these planets and benefit from their placement in the collective astrology.

The workshop will begin with the opportunity to explore powerful, enjoyable, accessible Voice Practices which open, align and strengthen your expression - and create physiological changes in your energy field.

We will then directly, bodily experience the energies of each of the Celestial Bodies through Embodied Astrology, guided by Clare.

We will integrate these energies, through further Voice Practices, including improvisation, healing chants and songs.

These two modalities will be carefully interwoven in an enjoyable, rich day's workshop that will benefit all participants.

There will be guided space in the workshop to integrate the energetic shifts and discoveries of both the Voice Practices and the Astrology.

This special workshop takes place on Saturday February 7th, 10am-4.30pm - we hope you can join us

At the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall, Paraparaumu.

INVESTMENT:

Your investment for this day is $233. Shared lunch.
Some concessions are available - please contact us by email .

Payment by card here - https://buy.stripe.com/aEU3g1gMecNj2SkbJI

Please contact us with any questions at all.

events.id: Danny Bhoy-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Danny Bhoy
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Danny Bhoy, New Zealand’s favourite Scottish comedian, is returning to The Opera House with his new show ‘Dear World’. His easy-going and intimate style of comedy brings banter and anecdotes that are sure to make you cackle. In ‘Dear World,’ Danny brings a thespian flair to the stage. “This is the sequel to my 2015 show ‘Dear Epson…’ My favourite ever show. It’s a hybrid of stand-up and theatre, but really that just means I get to sit down for bits of it.” 
Danny has been honing his craft and touring the world for over 25 years. Having built an impressive following in Australia, Canada and New Zealand, he knows his audience well and never shies away from playfully picking them apart. Described by The Montreal Gazette as “One of the most sparkling wits in the world,” and by The Age as having “unsurpassed storytelling”. This one-night-only show is sure to be one to remember.

events.id: Wellington Pasifika Festival--Wellington NZ
events.name: Wellington Pasifika Festival
events.long_description:
Experience the sights, sounds, and flavours of the Pacific. With over 15,000 people attending each year, the Wellington Pasifika Festival is a standout event for the regional and national calendar. This free, family-friendly festival celebrates the unique Pacific communities here in Wellington. There will be a special opening ceremony at midday, followed by live music and performances. Dotted around Waitangi Park, you’ll find stalls, a Kids’ Zone, stone carving, workshops, and plenty of delicious food. 
The younger ones can pick up a festival passport from the Kids’ Zone and collect stamps to win special prizes. Enjoy a festival experience based on the card game ‘Lalaga’, designed by Torisse Lalau, which uses Pasifika wisdom (talanoa) to foster empathy and connection through sharing stories. 
The theme for 2026 is ‘Arrival’ — a celebration of and a welcome to the Pasifika communities who have made New Zealand their home. Grab your friends and whanau and come along to soak up the island vibes and cultural celebrations.

events.id: Wellington Pasifika Festival 2026 🌺-Waitangi Park,24A Herd St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington-All Events In
events.name: Wellington Pasifika Festival 2026 🌺
events.venue: Waitangi Park,24A Herd St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
Wellington Pasifika Festival 2026 🌺
Experience the sights, sounds, and flavours of the Pacific at Wellington Pasifika Festival 2026 🌸🌴🥥

Come along to this free, whānau-friendly festival and join us to celebrate our unique Pacific communities. From art and language to performances and food, the Pasifika Festival is all about acknowledging the richness of our Pacific brothers and sisters.

📅Saturday 7 February 2026, at Waitangi Park, Wellington
⌚12pm-6pm for the main event. Come from 1:30am for the opening ceremony.
📍Waitangi Park, Wellington Waterfront

The 2026 event theme is ‘Arrival’, which will be represented through explorations of migration stories and is a celebration of and a welcome to the Pasifika communities who have made New Zealand their home. You can also view the carving has been taking shape since the 2024 festival and talk to artist Leo Semau about the artwork.

Plus... The popular Pasifika Cuisine Cook-Off competition is back for another year, with food stalls submitting their best dish for judging by a celebrity panel.

The festival will open with a blessing followed by stage performances from various Pacific Island groups. There will be food stalls, craft, and sponsor stalls, a Kids’ Zone, and Pacific Media Network 531pi FM and Āti Awa Toa radio activations.

You can also take part in a festival wide activation based on the card game ‘Lalaga’, designed by Torisse Lalau, which uses Pasifika wisdom (talanoa) to foster empathy and connection through sharing stories.

We’d like to thank the Pasifika Patrol who will be helping out on the day. Gather your friends and family for a fun day out–be transported to the Pacific Islands for the day! ❣️

To see the full programme, head to 👉 https://wellington.govt.nz/news-and-events/events-and-festivals/pasifika-festival

events.id: Nevers (France/Australia) / Jean-Philippe Gross (solo) / Oghum-Pyramid Club,272 Taranaki Street, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: Nevers (France/Australia) / Jean-Philippe Gross (solo) / Oghum
events.venue: Pyramid Club,272 Taranaki Street, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Nevers (France/Australia) / Jean-Philippe Gross (solo) / Oghum
Nevers
Featuring Clare Cooper (Australia) on guhzeng and Jean-Philippe Gross (France) on electro-acoustic devices, Nevers sometimes sounds like a fire in an electronic flea market, other times like the amplification of an insect funeral march. The duo finds common ground between Clare Cooper’s Chinese guhzeng and Jean-Philippe Gross’ lo-fi microphones, electroacoustic devices and localized speaker system.



Strasbourg’s Jean-Philippe Gross will also perform a solo set, of electronic music using a dedicated feedback system.
https://jeanphilippegross.com/

Clare Cooper is a musician and Design Lecturer from Sydney. Her work in creative community projects includes collaborative composition, speculative design, and critical listening. She co-founded the NOW now (2001), Splinter Orchestra (Sydney 2000), Splitter Orchester (Berlin 2009), and Frontyard Projects (2016).

Jean-Philippe Gross (Strasbourg – France) is a composer and improviser, performing with a dedicated feedback system often utilising multiple small speakers positioned around the performance space. In the studio, he continues his research with a “Serge modular system”. He has composed music for dance and performance, as well as for contemporary ensembles such as Ensemble Dedalus.

Nevers is presented with the support of Rise / La Muse en Circuit - Musica.

---

Oghum is the interstellar duo of Nell Thomas (Orchestra of Spheres, Cookie Brooklyn and the Crumbs) and Jonny Marks (All Seeing Hand, Mean Bones), performing on Synthi AKS, theremin and other assorted items. Oghum blends electronic sounds from times past with an array of acoustic and found sounds, using nuanced improvisation to create detailed and tangible sonic environments, invoking memory and transporting the listener through narrow gaps into wide open otherworldly spaces.

$20 presale tickets via UTR

Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme
events.description:
Nevers (France/Australia) / Jean-Philippe Gross (solo) / Oghum Nevers Featuring Clare Cooper (Australia) on guhzeng and Jean-Philippe Gross (France) on electro-acoustic devices, Nevers sometimes sounds like a fire in an electronic flea market, other times like the amplification of an insect funeral march.
Strasbourg’s Jean-Philippe Gross will also perform a solo set, of electronic music using a dedicated feedback system.
https://jeanphilippegross.com/ Clare Cooper is a musician and Design Lecturer from Sydney.
Her work in creative community projects includes collaborative composition, speculative design, and critical listening.
She co-founded the NOW now (2001), Splinter Orchestra (Sydney 2000), Splitter Orchester (Berlin 2009), and Frontyard Projects (2016).

events.id: Steffanie Holmes' Wellington Book Launch: A Grave Mistake-Entry via doors between Platypus Shoes and Stirling Sports, Level 1/55 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Steffanie Holmes' Wellington Book Launch: A Grave Mistake
events.venue: Entry via doors between Platypus Shoes and Stirling Sports, Level 1/55 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Steffanie Holmes' Book Launch of 'A Grave Mistake'.
The second book in The Nevermore Murder Club & Smutty Book Coven series.

Interconnected standalone series about the members of a supernatural book club finding their happily-ever-afters in a small town infested with vampires. Set in the same world as the Nevermore Bookshop, but eight years after.
Steffanie Holmes is a USA TODAY bestselling author of paranormal romance, urban fantasy, and supernatural mysteries. Her books feature clever, witty heroines, dark and gothy settings, cunning witches, and a dash of sadistic humour.
A Grave Mistake is the second book in The Nevermore Murder Club & Smutty Book Coven series, following Fangs for Nothing. This cosy paranormal romance blends enemy vampires who were once lovers, a meddling book club, a murder mystery, and more tea than should be legal, all with darkly witty, vampy charm.
Arabella Lestrange was once the most notorious dancer in Paris’ underground vampire cabaret, until she fell for a human, Gideon Blake, and he ruined her afterlife. She fled certain he wouldn’t survive long… only to encounter him 150 years later, newly undead and just as infuriatingly charming. It’s a story of revenge, romance, immortality, and meddling friends - all with a darkly witty twist.
This is a second-chance romance with the first romance happening in 18th-century Belle Epoque Paris, where the heroine is a pole dancer at a vampire cabaret (Le Petite Mort). Which means the launch needs a stage worthy of vampires and pole dancers alike...
Event Details
Date: Saturday 7 February
Time: 6–8 PM
Location: Pole Electric, Cuba Street
Hosted by: The Grimoire - NZ's Special and Limited Edition Bookstore

On the Night
Hosted by The Grimoire
Live reading by Steffanie Holmes
Audience Q&A (submit questions in advance to hello@thegrimoire.co.nz)
Two pole performances
Drinks (alcoholic and non-alcoholic) and nibbles provided in ticket price
Photo ops and time to chat with Steff
Character artwork - Gifted by Steff
Purchase your SIGNED sprayed edge trade paperbacks of both books on the night

The second book in The Nevermore Murder Club & Smutty Book Coven series.
Set in the same world as the Nevermore Bookshop, but eight years after.
Her books feature clever, witty heroines, dark and gothy settings, cunning witches, and a dash of sadistic humour.
This is a second-chance romance with the first romance happening in 18th-century Belle Epoque Paris, where the heroine is a pole dancer at a vampire cabaret (Le Petite Mort).

events.id: Estère – NZ Tour!-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Estère – NZ Tour!
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.long_description:
Estère is a Cameroonian Kiwi artist, producer and DJ known for her self-coined genre electric blue witch-hop, a vivid fusion of electronic production, vintage textures, afro-fusion and folk. A self-taught beat-maker, multi-instrumentalist and vocalist, she creates immersive sonic worlds shaped by elastic harmonies, intricate rhythms and playful found-sounds. Her soulful, expressive voice anchors her storytelling, exploring personal, mythical and political themes. 
With three acclaimed albums and an ASMR inspired EP, Estère has earned praise from Elle Magazine France, Afropunk, RNZ, The Guardian and more. Her production credits include collaborations with Jordan Rakei, Deva Mahal and Oddisee, and she placed Top 10 in the global Stonesthrow Records beat-making competition. In 2023 she released “Finer” with Nightmares on Wax on Warp Records. 
A magnetic live performer, Estère has opened for Grace Jones, Erykah Badu, Peaches and Hiatus Kaiyote, and performed at festivals worldwide including Glastonbury, Afropunk Paris, WOMAD, Bushfire and Sori Arts Festival. She has headlined sold-out shows across the UK, France and New Zealand, and was twice nominated for the Aotearoa Music Awards 
Her creative range extends into conceptual performance, including her 2020 show Into the Belly of Capricorn and her role as the first-ever headline artist for the World of Wearable Art Awards Show in 2022. 
Now based in London, Estère is entering a new chapter inspired by reconnecting with her Cameroonian heritage. She has begun weaving her tribal language Bassa and other African languages into her songwriting, themes that shape her forthcoming 2026 album Diaspora Baby. She also founded DiaxXpora, a London-based community and event series celebrating creatives from diaspora backgrounds

Estère is a Cameroonian Kiwi artist, producer and DJ known for her self-coined genre electric blue witch-hop, a vivid fusion of electronic production, vintage textures, afro-fusion and folk.

events.id: Pasifika Festival's Shooting Star Programme presents: Taula-12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Pasifika Festival's Shooting Star Programme presents: Taula
events.venue: 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Show title: "Taula (Anchor)"
Wellington City Council's Shooting Star Programme proudly presents an original theatre production, which debuts at the Hannah Playhouse on Saturday 7 Febrary 2026! This production centres themes of identity, belonging, the passing down of cultural traditions and the importance of family, both present and past. The story follows young people navigating their identity whilst figuring out their place in Educational spaces. Taula is performed by Māori, Pasifika and Asian rangatahi who are emerging and aspiring actors. Join us for a 50-minute show followed by a short talanoa/chat afterwards.
Bookings required due to venue seating capacity - all tickets are free.
More about The Shooting Star Programme:
Following on from a successful pilot programme in 2025 Étū rere pā‘ata - The Shooting Star Programme is back. Part of the Wellington Pasifika Festival, this programme sees a group of young Pasifika actors create a show which tells Pasifika stories. This performance is their theatre debut. The Shooting Star programme brings new artforms and performers to the Pasifika Festival, upskills a new cohort of Pasifika and Māori performers and celebrates Pasifika art. Created by Karl Kite Rangi with support from WCC City Events and with assistant directors Meilani Payne and Maddy Vai-Little.

events.name: Amitayus Retreat - free event
events.venue: 174 Albert Street, New Zealand 4410,174 Albert St, Hokowhitu, Palmerston North 4410, New Zealand, Palmerston North
events.long_description:
Amitayus Retreat - free event
Long life, merit and wisdom.
In this special retreat we have the opportunity to increase our lifespan, merit and wisdom through the special meditation practice of Buddha Amitayus.

Our human life is our most precious possession because it gives us the opportunity to improve ourselves and attain the supreme happiness of enlightenment.
We therefore need a long and healthy life. To engage successfully in spiritual practice we also need wisdom, as well as the merit or good fortune that gives our mind the strength to support the growth of inner realisations. Amitayus is the Buddha of long life, merit and wisdom.

By engaging in Amitayus practice, we can develop these qualities and eventually attain the deathless state of enlightenment.
We can also use this practice to help remove obstacles endangering the lives of others, especially our close friends and family.

SESSION TIMES
10 – 11.15am
12 – 1.15pm
3 – 4.15pm

DETAILS
There is no cost and you can attend as many sessions as you like.
Coffee, tea and snacks are provided. Please bring your own vegetarian lunch if you are staying for the whole day.

events.name: Greytown Heritage House & Garden Tour
events.venue: Greytown Village,Greytown, Parkvale, New Zealand, Clareville
events.long_description:
Greytown Heritage House & Garden Tour
Greytown is renowned for charming settler houses and lush gardens that thrive on rich alluvial soil.
The 2026 Greytown Heritage House and Garden Tour offers an opportunity to explore some of the town’s most remarkable properties.

Greytown Heritage Trust’s self-guided tour takes you through the gate and over the threshold – some of these houses will be opening publicly for the very first time.

So, spend an indulgent summer day weaving through the picturesque town’s streets, exploring our evident history. In joining us, you will be actively supporting the conservation of our heritage.

events.id: The Italians of Island Bay Second Edition 2026-Shorland Park,17 Reef St, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: The Italians of Island Bay Second Edition 2026
events.venue: Shorland Park,17 Reef St, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The Italians of Island Bay Second Edition 2026
Details to follow closer to time, but already got a few new ideas for the 2026 edition.

***

Description from Inaugural 2025 Edition FYI:

I would like to acknowledge the support of The Island Bay Festival, which will be celebrating its 40th year of bringing the community together this year, and thank them for giving me a space in The Park this Sunday at The Day in The Bay to showcase and celebrate The Italians of Island Bay, their history and their contributiion to the community, business and culture.

#supportlocal
#celebratelocal
#celebratecommunity
#islandbayfestival

The majority of Island Bay Italians are Neapolitan from the hill top town of Massa Lubrense and surrounds on the Sorrentine Peninsula, followed by Sicilians from the small volcanic island of Stromboli in the Aeolean sea.

When you think of The Italians of Island Bay you might think of their involvement and contribution to the Fishing and Food (and related) Industries, but it goes much wider than that..

In alphabetic order as to not to offend. NB: list a work in progress.

- academics
- accountants
- artists
- authors
- builders
- cinema
- electricians
- exporters
- film makers
- financial advisors
- fishermen
- footballers
- hairdressers
- hoteliers
- importers
- journalists
- lawyers
- lecturers
- lawn bowlers
- management consultants
- martial arts instructors
- mozzarella makers
- musicians
- olympic medalist
- opera singers
- photographers
- plumbers
- poets
- property developers
- public servants
- publishers
- quantity surveyors
- realaters
- restauranteurs
- scholars
- seamstresses
- secretaries
- retailers
- tailors
- teachers
- tomatoe growers
- volunteers
- wine makers
- wholesalers

Books that will on display:

- Alle Fine del Mondo by Paul Elenio
- Le Famiglie Strombolani by
- Food & Family by
- Family Business by Vincent Moleta
- Angelina by Gerard Hindmarsh
- Unsheltered by Clare Moleta
- Umberto Saba : poetry & prose selected & translated, with notes by Vincent Moleta

Just a few days to go till the big Day in the Bay on Sunday. I'm unexpectedly in Perth for family reasons, so have had to piece this together organically long distance, with the help and contribution of my mum's childhood girlfriends from The Bay, for which I'm extremely greatfull.

My Back-Story:

On my mother's side I'm double 4th generation Strombolana-Kiwi and 2nd generation Dutch-Kiwi on my father's side (RIP).. thus my long and unusual name..

Rosina Maria Giuseppina van der Aa.

All 4 of my biz-nonni (great grandparents) bravely sailed to the ends of the earth (alle fine del mondo) in search of a better future.

My maternal great grandfather (Bartolo Barnao) and his elder brother(Giuseppe) initially fished and slept under their fishing boat in Makara, before returning with their Strombolane wives who were also siblings (Giuseppina and Maria Concetta Pirera) to set up shop literally (a fish shop) in Palmerston North before then moving to No 64 The Parade Island Bay when my Nonna Rosina was 17 circa 1934.

My paternal great grandparents (Angelina Criscillo and Vincenzo Moleta) along with Vincenzo's brother (Antonino) and Angelina's cousin (Rosa) settled and tamed D'urville. My Nonno (Leslie George Moleta) spotted my Nonna (Rosina Elvira Barnao) at the Zino-Toscano wedding where she was a bridesmaid. They had two children, both named after their grandparents as was the tradition. My uncle Vincent Bartolo and my mother Maria Josephine The rest as they say is Family Business..

events.id: Scott Cook & Pamela Mae (CAN) at Abandoned Petone-154 Jackson St, Petone, Lower Hutt 5012-All Events In
events.name: Scott Cook & Pamela Mae (CAN) at Abandoned Petone
events.venue: 154 Jackson St, Petone, Lower Hutt 5012
events.long_description:
Scott Cook & Pamela Mae (CAN) at Abandoned Petone
Scott Cook and Pamela Mae - www.scottcook.net

Born in West Virginia and raised on the Canadian prairies, Scott Cook quit a job teaching kindergarten in Taiwan in 2007 to embark on the life of a full-time troubadour. He’s toured nearly nonstop across Canada, the US, Europe, Asia, Australia, New Zealand and elsewhere ever since, living out of backpacks and campervans, averaging over a hundred shows and a dozen summer festivals a year, and distilling his experiences into empathetic, keenly observant verse. Since 2022 he’s been joined full-time by his sweetheart Pamela Mae on upright bass and vocals, crisscrossing 45 US States and 8 Canadian provinces in their campervan Roadetta, and covering a fair bit of Australia in their HiAce Hector. In 2026 they’re bringing the duo project to New Zealand for the first time with an extensive tour of the North and South Islands in support of Cook's eighth album Troubadourly Yours. Fresh from the open road, these are sturdy, straight-talking songs that see the good in you.

“Whip-smart, bone-achingly lovely, socially committed songs presented with a bold, elegant directness evoking the very best of the folk music tradition. Last night's performance in Notional Space was a thing of rare beauty.” —Mark Jacobs, presenter, Notional Space

“He sings his heart and soul, and in doing so lets light flood into your own... He has a good eye for imagery, a gentle human touch, a wry sense of humour, a whole lot of integrity, a warm, rugged voice and a bunch of memorable lines... Truly one of Woody Guthrie's children.” –RnR Magazine

events.id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: SS Penguin Tour (Feb 2026)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: SS Penguin Tour (Feb 2026)
events.venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
On the 12 February 1909, the SS Penguin sank in Cook Strait in a raging southerly storm with the loss of 72 lives, one of the worst maritime disasters in NZ history.  Many of those who died were woman and children, as their lifeboats capsized in the wild sea. 
Although the Captain was heavily criticised, it is still not clear what the ship hit nor where, as the wreck of the Penguin has never been located. 
The tragedy stunned Wellington and a day of mourning was called for 16 February.  The city came to a standstill as many of those who died were brought up to Karori Cemetery for burial in a long procession of cabs and lorries.
To commemorate this tragedy the Friends will be undertaking a guided tour of most of the Penguin graves on Sunday 8th February. 
The tour duration is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour is suitable for people with moderate fitness. The route mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness. Surefootedness is required.

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you one hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

events.venue: 280 Church Street, New Zealand 4410,280 Church St, Palmerston North 4410, New Zealand, Palmerston North
events.long_description:
Improv for Life
This term-length programme is perfect for those who wish to grow confidence and creativity in a positive and safe learning space. Through the basics rules of improv learn to work with others, trust yourself, not be afraid to fail, develop public speaking skills, increase your listening prowess or all of the above!

The workshops are weekly, 90 minute sessions, designed to provide useful skills for everyday life through improv and fun!

No prerequisites are required, just bring your enthusiasm and a willingness to dive into the world of improvisation.

Improv for Life is designed to deliver both the goodies and the giggles for 18+ (exceptions may be made on a case-by-case basis).

Not intended for experienced improvisors.

events.id: Lagwagon ‘30th Anniversary of HOSS’ NZ Tour 2026-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Lagwagon ‘30th Anniversary of HOSS’ NZ Tour 2026
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.long_description:
California punk legends Lagwagon are heading back to Aotearoa in early 2026 to celebrate 30 years of their iconic album HOSS. This tour is all about reliving the raw energy and spirit of the '90s punk scene that HOSS helped define. 
Fans can look forward to hearing HOSS performed live in full - every track, start to finish - plus a bunch of fan favourites from their extensive catalogue. From the punchy riffs of "Violins" to the heartfelt "Razor Burn," it's a rare chance to experience the album that solidified Lagwagon's place in punk history.
Known for their high-energy, no-frills live shows, Lagwagon delivers the kind of performances that get the crowd moving and singing along. Whether you've been a fan since the '90s or just discovered them, this tour promises a night of pure punk rock.


San Fran holds a Supervised License. Minors are welcome to attend events at San Fran so long as they are accompanied by a legal guardian at all times whilst at the venue.

events.id: The Best of Bill Bryson — Live on Stage-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: The Best of Bill Bryson — Live on Stage
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
With 21 published nonfiction books, you’ll likely have come across Bill Bryson’s work. One of his most famous books, ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything’, has been given a major rewrite. He takes to the stage at The Opera House to talk about his new findings. 
In ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything 2.0’, Bill updates the book with the latest scientific research on the Earth and the universe. In the live show, you’ll hear about planetology, astronomy, particle physics, the Big Bang, quantum mechanics, and evolution. Throughout his career, the journalist and author has covered a wide range of subjects, including travel, the English language, and the human body. This rare chance to see him live promises forays into many of these areas. All conducted with his usual theatrical flair. 
Bill Bryson has a quest to understand everything that has happened from the Big Bang to the rise of civilisation and what humans are today. Join him as he shares the latest major advances in science.

events.id: A Place To Bury Strangers NZ Tour-Meow,9 Edward Street, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: A Place To Bury Strangers NZ Tour
events.venue: Meow,9 Edward Street, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
A Place To Bury Strangers NZ Tour
UTR and Meow Touring presents:

A Place To Bury Strangers return to Aotearoa with their explosive new album Synthesizer — a record built on chaos, colour, and pure DIY spirit. Synthesizer isn’t just the title of their seventh album; it’s also a custom-built instrument created specifically for it. “It’s pretty messed up, chaotic… but it feels really human,” says frontman Oliver Ackermann. The album celebrates spontaneity, collaboration, and the kind of raw noise that can only come from a band locked in together.

Written in the band’s Queens studio after a refreshed lineup — Ackermann with John and Sandra Fedowitz — Synthesizer cracks open and reimagines the signature APTBS sound in vivid new ways. It’s romantic, raw, unsteady, and built for the stage, where the band’s legendary walls of sound hit with full force.

With Support from: Grecco Romank

events.name: TechWomen and AWS - Career Mindset Workshop: Own Your Energy
events.venue: Multiple locations and online
events.long_description:
Kick off 2026 with a transformative mindset experience that will enable you to set and execute the right intentions for your career throughout 2026 and beyond.
The TechWomen and AWS teams invite you to begin the year with a special mindset workshop designed for women in tech, hosted by Candice Murray, a leading NZ based career mindset coach. In this interactive session, you'll choose a positive emotional state you want to strengthen - whether it's calm, confidence, self-belief, or focus - and learn practical, evidence-based techniques to access it whenever you need it most.
As the session is best experienced in person, we've arranged remote hubs around the country with Candice presenting live from Auckland. Discover how to harness your emotional power and elevate your professional performance through simple, science-backed tools that will equip you with lasting skills to thrive in your career.
Spaces are limited, so register early to secure your spot at this highly anticipated event.
Event Details:
Date: Wednesday, 11 February 2026
Time: 3:00pm - 5:30pm
Locations:
Auckland: AWS, Commercial Bay Level 13/15 Customs Street West, Auckland Central
Wellington: AWS, 21/157 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central
Hamilton : Tuatahi First Fibre, 11 Ken Browne Drive, Te Rapa, Hamilton
Christchurch (TBC)

events.long_description:
American indie-folk artist Gregory Alan Isakov is a Grammy-nominated singer and songwriter. He’s bringing his intimate and lyric-driven show to Wellington in February. Audiences will be given a special opportunity to experience stripped-down acoustic arrangements. He’ll delve into favourites from six of his full-length studio albums, including his most recent ‘Appaloosa Bones’.
